Scheme 1 A schematic diagram showing the synthesis process of different materials. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 The proposed preferential catalytic process over Pt/KZ-570A and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 XRD patterns (A) and TG profiles (B) of KZ-400 N (a), KZ-570A (b), KZ@MS-400 N and (c) and KZ@MS-570A (d) samples. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM and TEM images of KZ-400 N (a, e), KZ-570A (b, f), KZ@MS-400 N and (c, g) and KZ@MS-570A (d, h) samples. Fig 2 Fig. 3 27Al MAS NMR spectra (A) of KZ-400 N (a), KZ-570A (b), KZ@MS-400 N (c) and KZ@MS-570A (d) samples; 29Si MAS NMR spectra of KZ-400 N (B), KZ-570A (C), KZ@MS-400 N (D) and KZ@MS-570A (E) samples. Fig 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption isothermals (A) and BJH pore size distribution (B) of Pt/KZ-400 N (a), Pt/KZ-570A (b), Pt/KZ@MS-400 N (c) and Pt/KZ@MS-570A (d) samples.`. Fig 4 Fig. 5 HRTEM images of Pt/KZ-400 N (a), Pt/KZ-570A (b), Pt/KZ@MS-400 N (c) and Pt/ KZ@MS-570A (d) sample (the inset shows the histogram of Pt particle size distribution, based on the statistical analyses of 100 particles); HAADF-STEM images and the corresponding elemental mapping profiles of Pt/KZ@MS-400 N (e) and KZ@MS-570A (f). Fig 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of pristine Pt/KZ-400 N (a), Pt/KZ-570A (b), Pt/KZ@MS-400 N (c) and Pt/KZ@MS-570A (d) samples. The signal of desorbed NH3 was detected by mass spectrum. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Pyridine-adsorbed FT-IR spectra of Pt/KZ-400 N (a), Pt/KZ-570A (b), Pt/KZ@MS-400 N (c) and Pt/KZ@MS-570A (d) samples after desorption at 150 °C (A) and 300 °C (B). Fig 7 Fig. 8 (A) Curves of n-C16 conversion versus reaction temperature, (B) i-C16 yields versus n-C16 conversion, (C) i-C16 yields versus reaction temperature over Pt/KZ-400 N (a), Pt/KZ-570A (b), Pt/KZ@MS-400 N (c) and Pt/KZ@MS-570A (d) samples (D) the product distribution over different catalysts at the maximum i-C16 yield. Research Paper Boosting hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane by designing core-shell bifunctional catalysts with partially blocked micropores Bo Wang Writing – original draft Data curation a Xiaoni Wang Data curation a Zhifeng Li Investigation b ⁎ Hongxi Pan Formal analysis a Yang Song Data curation a Shuo Tao Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Energy Storage and Novel Cell Technology, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, Shandong 252059, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Energy Storage and Novel Cell Technology Liaocheng University Liaocheng Shandong 252059 China aShandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Energy Storage and Novel Cell Technology, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, Shandong 252059, China b Shandong Anshun Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd., Dezhou, Shandong 253600, China Shandong Anshun Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd Dezhou Shandong 253600 China bShandong Anshun Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd., Dezhou, Shandong 253600, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes is an indispensable route for upgrading fossil fuels and lubricant oils to meet the state of art regulations. Precisely regulate the distribution of acidic and metal active sites to suppress unwanted cracking reaction is hitherto a difficult task. In this work, we develop a simple coating-carbonation strategy for constructing novel core-shell bifunctional catalysts, comprising ZSM-22 zeolite core with the partially blocked channels and Pt nanoparticles loaded on the mesoporous SiO2 shell. The unique treatment not only adjusted the distribution of acid sites located within the micropore channels and external surface, but also alter the locations and dispersion of Pt nanoparticles. Owing to the short diffusion lengths, nanoscale distance between acid sites and Pt species, and high metal dispersions, the core-shell bifunctional catalyst exhibits outperformed performance in n-hexadecane hydroisomerization, i.e., the yield of isomerized hexadecane can reach 87.9 %, which is among the relatively high level compared with the previous reported Pt/zeolite counterparts. Moreover, the catalyst also displays excellent stability (no deactivation within 100 h). The disclosed structure-catalysis relationship provides rational reference for designing the synergistic meta-acid active sites in the hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Core-shell Zeolite Hydroisomerization Blocked micropores Bifunctional catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the increasingly stringent environmental regulations, there is a rising demand for the high-quality hydrocarbon fuels and lubricant oils in petrochemical industry. Hydroisomerization of n-alkanes to isomerized alkanes (i-alkanes) is an effective route for improving the octane/cetane number of fossil fuels and the cold-flow properties of lubricant oils [1,2]. Especially, the branched isomers via skeletal isomerization of corresponding long-chain linear paraffins are benefited for producing diesel fuels and lubricant with lower freezing point and higher viscosity indices [3,4]. Accordingly, it is imperative to develop highly effective catalysts to suppress cracking reactions and elevate branched isomers yields for long-chain n-alkanes hydroisomerization process. The hydroisomerization of n-alkanes needs the participation of bifunctional catalyst including metal sites and acidic sites. Firstly, n-alkane dehydrogenates to n-alkene intermediate over metal sites, and then it diffuses to acidic sites to undergo a process of skeletal rearrangement. After that, the i-alkene travels back to metal sites and hydrogenates to i-alkane [5,6]. Simultaneously, the i-alkene intermediates may go through subsequent cracking through (s, p) β-scission or severe confinement polymerization, producing light alkanes or coke. In this sense, the key to improve the skeletal isomerization is to design the synergistic metal-acid bifunctional catalyst. Generally, the metal active sites were provided by noble metals, such as Pt [7] or Pd [8,9], and the purposively adopted acid sites focused on one-dimensional medium pore zeolites, such as ZSM-22 [10,11], SAPO-11 [12,13], ZSM-48 [14,15], ZSM-23 [16], SAPO-31 [17,18]. Particularly, ZSM-22 zeolite endowed with unidimensional 10-membered ring tubular channels (0.45 × 0.54 nm) displays unique shape-selectivity and good stability in industrial hydroisomerization [19–21]. It is well-acknowledged that the skeletal rearrangement of long chain n-alkanes over ZSM-22 zeolite is compiled with the pore-mouth and key-lock mechanism proposed by Martens et al. [22]. The former demonstrates that the selective skeletal isomerization of n-alkanes takes place on the acid sites at the pore mouths, and the latter points that the anchored monobranched isomers could stretch across the external surface and penetrate into the other pores. However, as for conventional unidimensional zeolites, the acid sites on the external surface may induce isomerization without shape-selectivity, and the acidity located inside the micropore channels may cause cracking side reaction of mono-branched isomers due to the steric hindrance and sluggish diffusion rate [23,24]. As for the metal sites, the location and dispersion, as well as the mutual intimacy with acidic sites are vital factors for isomerization performance [25–27]. Accordingly, to maximize the accessibility of the acid sites located in pore-mouth and construct the well-balanced metal-acidic sites are conducive to improve the selectivity of desired branched isomers for long-chain n-alkanes isomerization. One general strategy to solve above problems is to introduce more pore entrances by constructing nanosized or hierarchical zeolites [28–30]. For instance, Zhu's group [31] prepared ZSM-22 zeolite with reduced axis [001] channel length by employing mechanochemical bead-milling and porogen-directed recrystallization strategy. Wu et al. [32] employed the crystal growth inhibitor to fabricate the hierarchical Pd/SAPO-41. The shorted diffusion distance and intracrystalline mesopores alleviated diffusion hindrance and facilitated the isomerization selectivity. Tailoring the distribution of external acidity is another strategy. Taking ZSM-22 as an example, Wang et al. [33] reduced Brønsted acidity of ZSM-22 and elevated the i-dodecane isomer yield to 63.7 % by using a template protective and NH4 + exchange strategy. Niu et al. [34] passivated unwanted external surface acidity by coating highly siliceous ZSM-22 via epitaxial growth, yet this requires the complicated recrystallization steps. Notably, it was proved that the ZSM-22 pore-blockage technique could effectively reduce the accessibility of acidity and restrain the diffusion of n-alkenes inside the micropore channels [35]. In addition, de Jong's group [36–38] recently verified the metal-acidic sites with nanoscale intimacy can enhanced the selective isomerization significantly by intentionally located Pt active sites on the γ-Al2O3 binder rather than zeolites (Y, Beta, ZSM-22, MOR). The aforementioned enhancements were attributed to increase the possibility of pore-mouth and key-lock catalysis, facilitating the formation of branched isomers instead of undesired acid-cracking side products. Herein, we report a highly efficient core-shell bifunctional catalyst with partially blocked micropores via a simple coating-carbonation route. The micro/meso‑pore structure, acidic property and the Pt distribution have been characterized systematically. On the one hand, the partially filled channel dramatically reduced the accessibility of undesired acid sites inside micropore channels to alkene intermediates. On the other hand, aside from the Brønsted acidic sites inside the ZSM-22 zeolite, the core-shell structure promoted the uniform dispersion and selectively location of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on the mesoprous SiO2 shell (meso‑SiO2). Serving as the bifunctional catalyst in hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane, the as-fabricated core-shell bifunctional catalyst exhibited superior performance to conventional Pt/zeolite counterparts. The impact of acidity and porosity on product distribution was manifested through the comparison with catalysts treated in different methods. By correlating acidic, textural and metal properties to catalytic behavior, the structure-catalysis performance relationship was summarized. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The chemical reagents were used as received without any further purification. Potassium hydroxide (KOH), aluminum sulfate (Al2(SO4)⋅18H2O, 99 %), 1,6-diaminohexane (DAH), concentrated ammonia aqueous solution (NH3⋅H2O, 25 wt.%), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), anhydrous ethanol and concentrated HCl were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Silica sol (30 wt.%, SiO2) was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Tetraethyl orthosilicata (TEOS, 99 %) was obtained from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co. Tetramine platinum (II) nitrate ([Pt(NH3)4]⋅(NO3)2, 99.9 %) was bought from Sigma-Aldrich Chem. Co. 2.2 Synthesis of KZSM-22 zeolite Pristine KZSM-22 zeolite was synthesized via a hydrothermal method according to the literature previously reported [39]. Typically, KOH, Al2(SO4)⋅18H2O, DAH, and silica sol were mixed homogeneously following the above order. The composition of the aluminosilicate gel was as follows: 1 SiO2: 0.12 K2O: 0.023 Al2O3: 0.3 DAH: 40 H2O. After stirring for 4 h, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and hydrothermal crystallized at 160 °C under rotation (60 rpm) for 2 days. The as-synthesized KZSM-22 product was filtered, washed and dried overnight at 100 °C, denoted as KZ-As. A part of KZ-As powders were loaded in quartz tube and calcined in flowing N2 at 400 °C for 4 h, and another part of KZ-As powders were calcined at 570 °C in air for 12 h in a muffle furnace. The treated KZ-As powders were denoted as KZ-400 N and KZ-570A, respectively. 2.3 Synthesis of core-shell materials The core-shell materials were synthesized following a modified stöber method [40]. In a typical synthesis, 0.9 g of CTAB and 3 g of NH3⋅H2O were dissolved in 240 g of deionized water and 142.2 g of anhydrous ethanol under vigorous stirring. After stirring for 0.5 h, the KZ-As powders (0.9 g) were added into the above solution and ultrsonicated for 0.5 h Afterwards, 2.3 g of TEOS was added drop wise into the above system. The mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 6 h The white solid precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with deionized water and ethanol several times. The CTAB surfactant was removed from the products by refluxing in the solution containing ethanol (327.01 g) and concentrated HCl (6.2091 g, 37 wt.%) at 60 °C for 2 h The core-shell KZSM-22@meso‑SiO2 product (denoted as KZ@MS-As) was finally obtained after washing with ethanol three times and drying under vacuum. A part of KZ@MS-As powders were loaded in quartz tube and calcined in flowing N2 at 400 °C for 4 h, and another part of KZ@MS-As powders was calcined at 570 °C in air for 12 h in a muffle furnace. The treated core-shell materials were denoted as KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A, respectively. 2.4 Preparation of catalysts The bifunctional Pt-supported catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method with [Pt(NH3)4]⋅(NO3)2 as precursor. The zeolites powders (1.0 g) were impregnated with 0.5 mL of aqueous [Pt(NH3)4]⋅(NO3)2 solution (corresponding to 0.5 wt.% Pt) at 25 °C for 12 h The samples were then evaporated at 120 °C for 12 h to remove moisture. Afterwards, the mixture was pressed, crushed and sieved into particles with size between 20 and 40 mess. 2.5 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation resource (45 kV and 200 mA). The morphologies of all the materials were observed by using Thermo Fisher Scientific FIB-SEM GX4 electron microscopy. The microstructure and location of Pt particles and High-angle-annular-dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) were determined on Thermal Fisher Talos transmission electron microscope (TEM). Textural properties were derived from by argon adsorption-desorption isothermal on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. Prior to the test, the sample was degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 10 h The specific surface area was measured by using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The micropore volume and pore size distribution of mesopores were determined by t-plot method and Battet-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. Total pore volume was evaluated by the adsorbed amount at relative pressure P/P0 of 0.99. The27Al and 29Si MAS NMR spectra were performed on a Bruker AVANCE III 600 spectrometer. The former was conducted at a frequency of 156.4 MHz with the spinning rate of 14 kHz. And the latter was conducted at a frequency of 119.2 MHz with the spinning rate of 10 kHz. The bulk elemental composition was measured by Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES) on Aligent 720 instrument, and the surface chemical composition was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) on ESCALAB Xi instrument. The contents of C, H and N elements were determined by elemental analyzer on Vatio EL CUBE apparatus. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO chemisorption were executed on Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 apparatus. In NH3-TPD experiment, the sample (100 mg) was firstly outgassed at 550 °C for 1 h in He flow. After cooling down to 100 °C, ammonia gas was then injected into the system for 30 min. The physically adsorbed NH3 was removed by the flowing He gas for 1 h at 100 °C. Then the adsorbed sample was heated to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under He flow, and the signal was recorded by a mass spectrum simultaneously. During the CO pulse experiment, the sample was firstly reduced in a 10 vol% H2-Ar stream at 400 °C for 1 h After cooling down to 50 °C, 10 vol% COHe pulse was introduced into the system and the dose repeated for 20 times. The dispersion of Pt particles was calculated according to the CO gas concentration detected by TCD. Pyridine-adsorption FT-IR spectra were both performed on a Bruker Tensor 27 instrument in absorbance mode at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The sample was firstly pressed into a self-supported wafer and evacuated at 350 °C for 1 h After cooling down to ambient temperature, the sample was then exposed to pyridine vapor for 20 min. The desorption of pyridine was carried out at 150 °C and 300 °C, respectively. The FT-IR spectra were collected in the range of 1400–1580 cm−1. 2.6 Catalytic experiments The hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane (n-C16) was carried out in a stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor. Prior to catalysis experiments, the catalysts (0.75 g) were firstly reduced in situ with 5 vol.% H2 gas flow at 400 °C for 4 h Afterwards the system was cooled down to the initial reaction temperature and the feedstock of n-C16 was pumped into the reactor at a certain flow rate. The corresponding operational conditions were 2.0 h −1 WHSV, 0.3 MPa, H2/n-C16 = 15 (molar ratio). All the products were analyzed online by an Agilent 8890 gas chromatograph. The conversion of n-C16, the selectivity of i-C16 and C1 C13 cracking products and the yield of i-C16 were calculated by using the following formulas: Conversion ( % ) = the amount of n − C 16 consumed the amount of n − C 16 in × 100 % Selectivity of i − C 16 ( % ) = the amount of i − C 16 formed the amount of n − C 16 consumed × 100 % Selectivity of C 1 − C 13 ( % ) = the amount of C 1 − C 13 formed the amount of n − C 16 consumed × 100 % Yield ( % ) = the amount of i − C 16 formed the amount of n − C 16 in × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the series KZSM-22 and core-shell materials The as-synthesized KZSM-22 (denoted as KZ-As) were calcined at 400 °C and 570 °C, respectively, which were denoted as KZ-400 N and KZ-570A. The treated core-shell KZSM-22@meso‑SiO2 (denoted as KZ@MS-As) materials were denoted as KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A (for details see experimental section). Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of the series materials. The KZ-400 N and KZ-570A samples exhibit the characteristic peaks at 2θ degree of 8.1°, 20.28°, 24.14°, 24.56° and 25.66°, corresponding to the typical diffraction peaks of TON-type topology (JCPDS No.46–0569). As for the KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A materials, an additional broad diffraction at 2θ degree of ca. 4.3° is observed, indicating the formation of mesoporous phase [41]. Compared with the parent ZSM-22 zeolites, the weakened diffractions of TON structure for the two core-shell samples maybe due to the diluting effect of the mesoporous phase. In order to investigate the residue of organic template, we compared the TG curves of the series KZSM-22 zeolites and the core-shell samples (Fig. 1B and Fig. S1). The weight loss of KZ-AS sample is 7.88 %, which can be divided into two stages (Fig.S1). The first stage (2.11 %) below 200 °C is attributed to the desorption of physical adsorbed water. The second stage (5.77 %) above 200 °C is derived from the decomposition and combustion of organic template. Upon the treatment at 400 °C, the weight loss of KZ-400 N sample located in the second stage decreases to 3.78 %, while the corresponding weight loss of KZ-570A sample is extremely low (0.67 %) (Table S1). It indicates there is still partial template remain in the KZ-400 N zeolite micoporous channel, and the template of KZ-570A sample may be completely removed due to the treatment at high temperature. The TG curves of core-shell KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A samples present the similar variation trend as KZ-400 N and KZ-570A samples, respectively. While the core-shell composites exhibited a higher weight loss (10.45 % and 7.91 % for KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A, respectively), which may be due to the residue of organic template within the mesoporous SiO2 shell. FT-IR spectra and element analysis come to the similar conclusion (Fig. S2 and Table S2). As for the KZ-400 N sample, the signal at 2900 cm−1 is assigned to CH vibration peaks [42], and the contents of carbon and nitrogen are 3.41 % and 0.58 %, respectively. The KZ@MS-400 N sample exhibits weak CH vibration signal and the contents of carbon and nitrogen species halve approximately with respect to KZ-400 N sample (1.91 % for carbon and 0.24 % for nitrogen) (Table S2). The variation is probably due to the dilution effect of the mesoporous SiO2 shell. Upon calcination, the CH vibration signal disappears and the content of nitrogen and carbon species decrease substantially for KZ-570A and KZ@MS-570A samples (0.16 % and 0.24 % for carbon, 0.02 % and 0.00 % for nitrogen), indicating the completed removal of the organic template. The morphology and microstructure of KZSM-22 zeolites and the core-shell composites were characterized by FE-SEM and TEM micrographs (Fig. 2 ). The pristine KZSM-22 zeolites, KZ-400 N and KZ-570A, exhibit a uniform aligned nanorod morphology with rough surface as well as well-defined edges and corners (Fig. 2a and 2b). The corresponding TEM images reveal that the KZ-400 N and KZ-570A nanorods have the dimensions of 500–900 nm in length and 50–80 nm in width (Fig. 2e and 2f). In contrast, the core-shell KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A materials show a slight increase in particle size and the emergence of a new phase emerged on the surface (Fig. 2c and d). TEM images of these materials demonstrate a spongy-like texture with the thickness of 30–50 nm coating on the pristine ZSM-22 crystal (Fig. 2g and 2h), indicative of a core-shell structure. The bulk and surface Si/Al ratio for all the materials were determined by XPS and ICP-AES, respectively (Table S2). The bulk Si/Al ratio of KZ-400 N and KZ-570A are 20.61 and 20.48, respectively, while the corresponding surface Si/Al ratio are 21.06 and 25.13. It indicates the silicon species are more abundant on the surface of KZSM-22 zeolites. After coating mesoporous phase, the bulk Si/Al ratios are approximately doubled to 39.59 and 39.69 for KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A, respectively. However, the surface Si/Al ratios increase remarkably to 166.44 and 130.96, demonstrating the added siliceous species are primarily located on the external surface of the KZSM-22 crystals. The results are in good agreement with the formation of a mesoporous SiO2 shell for KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A, as observed in SEM and TEM characterizations. To investigate the coordination environments of Al and Si atoms, 27Al and 29Si MAS NMR spectra were collected for all the samples. As shown in Fig. 3 , the KZ-400 N sample shows only one sharp signal at 58 ppm, assigning to Al specie in the tetrahedral (AlIV) coordination state [43,44]. The KZ-570A sample exhibits an extremely weak hexa-coordinated Al (AlVI) signal at 0 ppm, implying the appearance of extra-framework aluminum upon the calcination steps at high temperature [45]. After coating the mesoporous SiO2 phase, KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A samples exhibit the almost identical signal peak of AlIV and AlVI species, indicating the states of Al specie keep stable during the acid-treatment process. The 29Si MAS NMR spectra could be divided into four or five bands by using Gaussian function deconvolution integration. As for KZ-400 N and KZ-570A samples, the resonances centered at −113.8, −112.1 and −110.5 ppm are attributed to Q 4 (0Al) environment [46]. The broad peak at −104 ppm is assigned to Q 4 (1Al) and Q3 environment [47]. After coating mesoporous SiO2 shell, the new band centered at −115 ppm probably corresponds to the formation of mesoporous SiO2 phase [48], and the signals belonging to Q 4 and Q3 units keep almost unchanged, indicating the stable coordination environment of Si specie. As an advanced characterization technique, Ar adsorption-desorption was employed to assess the porous porosity of the samples (Fig. S3). The pristine KZ-400 N zeolite exhibits a type-I and type-IV isotherms of the typical micro/meso‑porous material. It presents a low uptake at low pressure (P/P0 < 0.1) region and a H3 hysteresis loop at high pressure region (P/P0 > 0.7), ascribing to the presence of intercrystalline voids caused by the stacking slits of nano-rods. As for KZ-400 N sample, the total volume is 0.2 cm3 g −1 and the microporous volume is just 0.01 cm3 g −1 (Table S3), which indicates microporous channels are partially blocked. The mesoporous volume of KZ-400 N sample is 0.19 cm3 g −1 with a mesoporous distribution of approximately 3.7 and 60 nm. The KZ-570A sample exhibits an obvious increase at the low pressure (P/P0 < 0.1) region and the corresponding surface area increases to 192.9 m2 g −1. As a result of template being completely removed the channels, the microporous volume of KZ-570A increases to 0.08 cm3 g −1 in comparision to KZ-400 N sample. As for the core-shell KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A samples, a steep increase in the medium pressure region (P/P0 = 0.1–0.6) and a more pronounced hysteresis loop are observed due to the formation of meso‑SiO2 shell. It is in line with the substantially increased surface area (489.3 m2 g −1 and 453.8 m2 g −1 for KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A, respectively) and mesoporous volume (0.35 cm3 g −1 and 0.21 cm3 g −1 for KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A, respectively). The mesoporous size of the meso‑SiO2 shell for the core-shell materials mainly distributes at 2.9 and 3.2 nm (Fig. S3). Combined with the above characterizations, the KZ-400 N zeolite and core-shell KZ@MS-400 N composite possess the partially filled microporous channels, while the KZ-570A zeolite and KZ@MS-570A composite were featured with completely evacuated micropores (Scheme 1 ). The Pt supported bifunctional catalysts were constructed by impregnation and reduction process. To investigate the state of organic template of Pt-supported catalysts, we measured the content of organic element before and after loading Pt NPs (Table 1 ). Compared to the KZ-400 N and KZ@MS-400 N supports, the contents of carbon and nitrogen for the corresponding Pt-supported catalysts slightly decrease (1.26 % and 0.17 % for Pt/KZ-400 N; 0.87 % and 0.11 % for Pt/KZ@MS-400 N), which are yet higher than the corresponding Pt/KZ-570A (0.13 % and 0.02 %) and Pt/ZM@MS-570 (0.24 % and 0.05 %) catalysts. The decrease of organic species demonstrates the residual template may be partially decomposed during the reduction process. Next, the pore architecture and texture property of the catalysts are compared with the supports. As shown in Fig. 4 , all the catalysts exhibit the same type isothermals and the comparable BJH pore size distribution curves with their supports. However, the corresponding mesoporous size for the Pt-supported catalysts are slightly narrower than their supports. Compared to KZ-400 N and KZ@MS-400 N supports, the total surface areas of Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts increase to 73.6 m2 g −1 and 468.9 m2 g −1, respectively, and the corresponding micropore volumes increase to 0.03 cm3 g −1 and 0.06 cm3 g −1 (Table 1). The increase may be derived from partially decomposition of the residue template during the reduction process of the Pt-catalysts in H2 atmosphere. Deep insight into the dispersion and location of Pt nanoparticles (Pt NPs) over the crystals were investigated by CO chemisorption and HRTEM images. As shown in Table 2 , compared to the Pt/KZ-500 catalyst, the Pt/KZ-400 N catalyst prepared through carbonation process possesses the minimum surface area (73.6 m2 g −1) and total pore volume (0.16 cm3 g −1), which thereby results in the lower dispersion (25.37 % vs 31.96 %) of Pt NPs. After coating mesoporous SiO2 shell, the surface area and pore volume of Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-500 catalysts are markedly increased, and the corresponding Pt dispersion rise to 80.67 % and 50.34 %, respectively. It indicates the coating and carbonation process could generate significant impact on metal distribution indirectly. From HRTEM images, the Pt NPs with an average size of approximately 2.4 and 2.2 nm are randomly dispersed around the rod-shaped crystals of the KZ-400 N and KZ-570A samples (Fig. 5 a and 5b). In the case of the core-shell KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A composites, the average sizes of Pt NPs decrease to 2.0 and 2.1 nm (Fig. 5c and 5d). There is a certain deviation between the dispersion and the particle size, which may be due to the encapsulation effect or the unidentified Pt species in sub-nanometer cluster states. The HAADF-STEM images exhibit the supported Pt NPs tend to distribute along the edges of the crystals for the core-shell composites (Fig. 5e and 5f). The corresponding elemental mapping profiles disclose the uniform distribution of Si, Al and Pt species around the core-shell materials. The acidic sites of the samples were determined by NH3-TPD profiles and pyridine-adsorption FT-IR spectra. In NH3-TPD experiment, mass spectrum was employed to accurately detect the signal of desorbed NH3. As shown in Fig. 6 , all the samples exhibite two major peaks centered at 178 °C and 414 °C, which are associated to the desorption of NH3 adsorbed on weak and medium strength acid sites, respectively. Compared to Pt/KZ-400 N catalyst, the peak value of Pt/KZ-570A catalyst slightly shifts towards higher temperature, meanwhile the high-temperature peak intensity enhances obviously, demonstrating more medium strong acid sites within the Pt/KZ-570A catalyst. By contrast, Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts represent much lower peak intensity, especially for the medium strong acidity. The Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst exhibits the substantial reduced weak acidity and unnoticeable medium-strong acidity. Pyridine adsorption FTIR were further employed as probe molecule to clarify the acidic properties. As shown in Fig. 7 , the band at 1548 cm−1 belongs to stretching mode of pyridine bonded to Brønsted acid sites, and the band at 1447 cm−1 is linked to Lewis acid sites [49]. The calculated acidity of various Brønsted and Lewis acid sites desorbed at 150 °C and 300 °C are listed in Table 2. Compared to Pt/KZ-400 N catalyst, the Pt/KZ-570A catalyst exhibits higher amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites after desorption at both 150 °C and 300 °C. In terms of the core-shell catalysts, the Brønsted sites desorbed at 150 °C and 300 °C decreases significantly, and the corresponding B/L ratios lower to 0.26 for Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and 0.55 for Pt/KZ@MS-570A, respectively. Especially, the Pt/KZ-570A catalyst represents the largest amount of Brønsted acid sites (13.99 and 9.75 μmol/g), and the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst demonstrates the minimal Brønsted acid sites (5.34 and 3.35 μmol/g) among all the catalysts. On basis of the above result, the various acid strength and content mainly root in the different structure and treatment of the supports. The KZ-570A support suffering from the calcination at a high temperature exhibits the complicatedly evacuated channels, therefore the acid sites inside and external surface are fully accessible to probe molecules. By contrast, the template of KZ-400 N support is partially removed at the low temperature and the microporous channels are partially filled, reducing the accessibility of probe molecules to the inside acid sites. As for the KZ@MS-400 N and KZ@MS-570A supports, the mesoporous SiO2 shell results in the substantial reduction of external surface acid sites, especially for the Brønsted acid sites. Accordingly, the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst is featured with the mesoporous shell and partially blocked channels, manifesting the least amount of Brønsted acid sites. The boosting Lewis acid may be related to the insertion of Al species into the mesoporous shell. 3.2 Hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane over different catalysts The hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane was conducted to evaluate the performance of the bifunctional catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 A, the conversion basically increases with the raising reaction temperature for all the catalysts. Compared to the Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ-570A catalysts, the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts require a higher reaction temperature to reach the equivalent conversion, revealing the evidently lower activity for the core-shell catalysts. Meanwhile, the catalysts calcined at a higher temperature including Pt/KZ-570A and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts exhibit a much higher activity than the corresponding Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts, respectively. Through the comparison of calcination temperature and atmosphere of the core-shell materials, KZ@MS powders treated at 500 °C exhibit slightly higher activity than the equivalent samples treated at 400 °C in the same atmosphere, implying the calcination temperature has generated somewhat influence on catalytic activity (Fig. S4B). It indicates that the hydroisomerization of long-chain alkanes was mainly catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites [50. 51]. The substantial reduction of Brønsted acid sites for Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts (Fig. 7 and Table 2) mainly accounts for the lower hydroisomerization activity. By contrast, Pt/KZ-570A catalyst with the largest amount of accessible acidity exhibits the highest hyisomerization activity. Fig. 8B shows the isomerized hexadecane (i-C16) yield versus the n-C16 conversion over different catalysts. The maximum i-C16 yield over the four catalysts decreases in the order of Pt/KZ@MS-400 N > Pt/KZ-400 N > Pt/KZ@MS-570A > Pt/KZ-570A. In detail, the maximum i-C16 yield over Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst is 87.9 %, which is 4.3 % and 11.8 % higher than that of the Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalyst, and a significant increase than that of the Pt/KZ-570A catalyst (42.6 %). To the best of our knowledge, the maximum i-C16 yield (87.9 %) is among the relatively high level compared with the previous reports (Table S4). In addition, the maximum i-C16 yield over KZ@MS-570 N and KZ@MS-400 N catalysts is larger than that of the comparable KZ@MS-570A and KZ@MS-400A catalysts, implying the treated atmosphere appears to have a bigger influence on the i-C16 yield (Fig. S4). The i-C16 yield was plotted versus reaction temperature for the four catalysts, as shown in Fig. 8C. Compared to the Pt/KZ-570A and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts, the maximum yield is obtained at a higher temperature for the corresponding Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts. It is worth noting a relative high i-C16 yield (>70 %) can be obtained in a much wider temperature range (290–320 °C) for the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst than the other three catalysts, indicating a wider operation temperature window for the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst. The product distributions over the four catalysts at their maximum i-C16 yield are presented in Fig. 8D. Typically, as for the Pt/KZ-570A catalyst, the cracking products account for a large proportion (48.4 %), and the proportion of mono- (22.26 %) and multi-branched i-C16 (29.34 %) isomers are close. With respect to the Pt/KZ-400 N, Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts, the mono-branched i-C16 isomers dominates the products, which are almost doubled the yield of multi-branched isomers. Amongst, the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst shows the highest yield of branched i-C16 isomers (87.9 %) and the multi-branched isomers (35.26 %). Long-term performances of the Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst was evaluated (Fig. 8E). The n-C16 conversion could be kept around 93 %, and the selectivity and yield of i-C16 isomer could be kept around 91.7 % and 86.1 % in >100 h’ runs. It suggests the excellent activity and stability for the core-shell bifunctional Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst. After 100 h’ runs, the spent Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst was further characterized. As shown in Fig. S5, XRD patterns of the spent catalyst keep almost unchanged compared with the fresh catalyst (Fig. S5), indicating the stable crystallinity in the duration. The weight loss of the spent catalyst is 7.52 % higher than the fresh catalyst, which may be derived from the residual reactants and products in microporous channels of the catalyst during the reaction. To further investigate the reaction process of the catalysts, the product distribution versus n-C16 conversion are presented in Fig. S6. When the n-C16 conversion is low (<20 %), the dominant product over all the catalysts are mono-branched i-C16 isomer, and the multi-branched i-C16 isomer are similar for the different catalysts. With the n-C16 conversion increasing to 80 %, the yield of mono-branched i-C16 isomer gradually increases, thus the distributions of mono-branched and multi-branched isomers become larger, especially for the Pt/KZ-400 N, Pt/KZ@MS-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts. The variation trend obeys with the “pore mouth” mechanism that the mono-branched isomers are firstly formed at the pore mouth of the support. When the conversion increases exceeds 90 %, the yield of mono-branched rapidly declines and becomes less than the yield of multi-branched i-C16 isomers. In addition, the specific distribution of cracking products at the maximum yield is depicted in Fig. 9 . All the products were analyzed online using a gas chromatograph. The specific retention times of each products and reactant are presented in Fig. S7. It is well acknowledged that the cracking of n-alkanes mainly involves four β–scission cleavage modes (Scheme. S1), and the relative rates strongly decrease from type A to type D [54]. As known to all, the cracking is hardly occur at low temperature, and the extent of cracking gradually increases with the conversion. When the conversion is relative high, the secondary cracking of the former cracked fragments also occurs in addition to the once cracking of C16 carbocations [10]. Generally, the heavy crack products (C8 C15) are produced by the once cracking of C16 carbocations, while the light crack products (C1 C7) can also be produced via the secondary cracking. As for the Pt/KZ-570A and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts, the main cracking products focus on the C4 C8 alkanes, while for Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts, the cracking products of C8 C13 alkanes increased obviously. The specific distribution of the cracking products is not only related to the acidic sites but also associated with the diffusivity within the crystals. Based on the previous research, as for the Pt/KZ-570A and Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalysts, the evacuate channels force the once cracked products to diffuse into the micropores channels, which results in the occurrence of secondary cracking and formation of light crack products. However, the partially filled channel within Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts may promote to the diffusion of the once cracked products around the micropore mouths, which significantly suppress the secondary cracking reaction [35]. On the ground of classical metal-acid bifunctional mechanism, the long-chain n-alkanes firstly undergo dehydrogenation to corresponding olefin intermediates over metal sites, and then the skeletal isomerization of olefin intermediates occurs over acid sites via the formation of carbenium ion. Since the isomerization is much slower than the dehydrogenation/hydrogenation process, the ideal hydroisomerization process needs the fast diffusion of i-alkene intermediates to metal sites to undergo subsequent hydrogenation. With respect to the 10-ring one-dimensional medium pore zeolites, it is acknowledged the isomerization of olefin intermediates follows the pore-mouth and key-lock catalysis [52]. For the Pt/KZ-570A catalyst, the olefin intermediates might be trapped in evacuated micropore channels, which increases the residence time and the diffusion restriction to a large extent. Meanwhile the accessible acid sites located in the micropore channels or on the external surface promote the unwanted once and secondary cracking side reactions, leading to the loss of isomer yield (Scheme 2 ). The formation of mesoporous SiO2 (meso‑SiO2) shell for Pt/KZ@MS-570A catalyst covers the partial acid sites on the external surface and constricts Pt NPs into the shell forming the nanoscale distance with acid sites, which may facilitate the isomerization course during reaction. As for the Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts with partially blocked micropore channels, the straight long-chain side of olefin intermediates have to penetrate into the adjacent pore mouth, which suppresses the secondary cracking and results in the formation of multi-branched isomers instead of cracking products. In addition, it indicates the nanoscale intimacy between metal active sites and acid sites has a strong influence on the catalytic performance [53]. Compared with Pt/KZ-400 N and Pt/KZ-570A catalysts, Pt NPs of the core-shell Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst depositing on the mesoporous SiO2 shell generate the nanoscale distance with acid sites, which is beneficial for the production of branched isomers. The alkene intermediates formed on Pt active sites rapidly diffuse to acid sites of ZSM-22 zeolites, reducing the residence time and diffusion path and suppressing the serious cracking side reaction. Especially, the core-shell Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalysts outperforms the other ZSM-22 counterparts with the overall highest isomer yield and multi-branched isomers selectivity due to the combined effect of partial filled channel and meso‑SiO2 shell. 4 Conclusions In present work, a novel core-shell Pt/KZ@MS-400 N catalyst composing of ZSM-22 zeolite core and mesoporous silica shell was constructed by a coating-carbonation strategy. For one hand, the partially blocked micropores diminish the diffusion restrict and accessibility of the acid sites inside the micropores. For the other hand, the formation of mesoporous shell not only covers the acid sites on the external surface, but also facilitates the deposition and confinement of Pt NPs, generating the nanoscale distance with acid sites. The synergistic effects suppress unwanted cracking side reactions to a large extent and boost the isomerization reaction, contributing to a substantially elevated isomer yield (87.9 %) and long-term stability, as well as the wide operating temperature conditions. The coating-carbonation strategy is potentially extendable to other core-shell unidimensional zeolites, which opens new avenues for the fabrication of bifunctional catalysts for long-chain-alkanes hydroisomerization process. coredata.dc:description: Hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes is an indispensable route for upgrading fossil fuels and lubricant oils to meet the state of art regulations. Precisely regulate the distribution of acidic and metal active sites to suppress unwanted cracking reaction is hitherto a difficult task. In this work, we develop a simple coating-carbonation strategy for constructing novel core-shell bifunctional catalysts, comprising ZSM-22 zeolite core with the partially blocked channels and Pt nanoparticles loaded on the mesoporous SiO2 shell. The unique treatment not only adjusted the distribution of acid sites located within the micropore channels and external surface, but also alter the locations and dispersion of Pt nanoparticles. Owing to the short diffusion lengths, nanoscale distance between acid sites and Pt species, and high metal dispersions, the core-shell bifunctional catalyst exhibits outperformed performance in n-hexadecane hydroisomerization, i.e., the yield of isomerized hexadecane can reach 87.9 %, which is among the relatively high level compared with the previous reported Pt/zeolite counterparts. Moreover, the catalyst also displays excellent stability (no deactivation within 100 h). The disclosed structure-catalysis relationship provides rational reference for designing the synergistic meta-acid active sites in the hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes.
